Absolutely! Rent control is one of the most effective tools cities have to protect housing affordability, especially for lower- and middle-income residents. At its core, rent control limits how much landlords can increase rent over time, which helps stabilize housing costs and prevent sudden, unaffordable spikes.

In the long run, rent control ensures that people who have lived in a community can continue to do so without being priced out. Without such protections, landlords—especially in high-demand areas—can raise rents rapidly in response to market conditions. This often forces long-term residents, including seniors, families, and essential workers, to move out because they can no longer afford their homes.

One of the key benefits of rent control is that it creates a predictable and stable housing environment. Tenants know exactly what their rent will be in the future, which helps them plan their budgets and stay in their homes. This stability is crucial for housing affordability because it reduces the financial stress and uncertainty that can come with rent increases.

Moreover, in cities where rent control is in place, we see a significant portion of the housing stock remains accessible to lower-income households. For example, in cities like New York and San Francisco, rent-controlled units serve as a critical buffer against homelessness and housing insecurity. These units are often the only affordable option for many residents who would otherwise be forced into overcrowded living situations or even displacement.

Another important point is that rent control encourages long-term investment in housing by landlords. When landlords know that they can’t raise rents arbitrarily, they are more likely to maintain and improve their properties to attract and retain tenants. This leads to better-maintained housing stock and a healthier living environment for residents.

Ultimately, rent control is not a magic solution, but it is a proven strategy that helps keep housing costs in check and ensures that housing remains affordable for a diverse cross-section of the population over time. It plays a vital role in maintaining the social and economic fabric of communities.
